attributes.alt: Book cover for The Way I Feel by Janan Cain. The cover shows a child's face upside down with eyes crossed.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with feelings movements, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book. Ask,
What different feelings can people have?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts; Ask and answer questions to seek help or information; Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use varied types of words; Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants; Understand words similar in meaning.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Have children create Feeling Plates out of paper plates and art supplies.
Invite children to use their Feeling Plates to indicate what they’re feeling.
How do we talk about and manage our feelings?
What feelings do some of your favorite characters show?
Act out one of the feelings you saw in the
Look around. How many feelings can you see on people’s faces?
Can you write a story about a happy day?
Make a colorful drawing to show how you feel right now.
Use blocks to make a face with a big smile. How many feelings can you show with blocks?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill, talk about feelings, and introduce vocabulary
What makes you feel happy or proud?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.

different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Have children look at pictures and say if a happy or sad feeling is shown.

How do we talk about and manage our feelings?
Find stories with characters who are happy.
Show how you would try to help someone who’s having a hard time with their feelings.
Can you find three smiling children in your class? Count them.
Draw a picture to show your friend you are happy.
Use molding clay to make a heart. Share it with a friend.
What other materials can you use to make a heart?

attributes.alt: A chart with the title If You're Happy and You Know It. Children's faces are next to speech bubbles that say Happy, Sad, Angry, Scared, Surprised, Silly, Excited, and Loved.

elements.text: If You’re Happy and You Know It

attributes.alt: Book cover for The Way I Feel by Janan Cain. The cover shows a child's face upside down with eyes crossed.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about all of the different feelings the children have learned about, play a game of “Simon Says,” and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
If You’re Happy and You Know It
Use language for different purpose and match language to social contexts; Ask and answer questions to seek help and information; Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use varied types of words; Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants; Understand words similar in meaning.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Have children look at picture cards and identify the feeling by the action the person in the picture is doing.
Invite children to repeat the action they see in the picture.
How do we talk about and manage our feelings?
Sing the words to the song “If You’re Happy and You Know It.”
Pretend you are surprised. What action would you show?
How many actions can you use to show that you are happy?
Write about what you like to do when you’re happy.
Draw a line down the center of a piece of paper. Draw yourself happy on one side and sad on the other.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you build something very silly out of blocks?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have a Feelings Parade, play an letter game, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book. Ask,
How can you feel better when you are sad?
Read and retell interactively for emotional development.

Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
“What can we learn from our feelings?”
Save children’s writing to display next week.

What stories have you read that show how children talk about their feelings?

Find out how many of your classmates have the same favorite feeling as you.
Draw a feeling that you do not like.
Draw a big heart and add things you love inside of it.
sound. Can you think of any words that start with the letter
Create a scary scene. What can you change to make it less scary?

Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers/adults.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
